@jack-moseley Can you check on travis failure?

Well, one problem could be that lombok may liberally use any dependency as they wish, no matter how outdated. Then including lombok in Gobblin's runtime means needlessly pulling those transitive dependencies into classpath.
 
Why needlessly? because one of lombok promises is: zero runtime dependency. No code path within lombok is accessed during runtime. No other third-party library is used within lombok's generated code either. The generated code is just pure vanilla java.
All those lombok annotations we add to the code, and lombok.* package references are all removed during AST transformation. 
So why include it's jar and its transitive dependencies at all?
